august_8_2011_playing_lefties.diagnostic: Left-handers’ trajectories and common placements differ; natural placements used vs right-handers become poor choices vs left-handers.
causes_communes: Aggressive crosscourt backhands from lefties expose the wide forehand
Forehand serves into your forehand that break away
Defaulting to righty-oriented placements (e.g., steady to backhand, quick to forehand) which feed a lefty’s strengths

debutant: Get repetitions vs lefties to normalize their ball flight; expect crosscourt backhand to your wide forehand and breaking forehand serves.
On lefty forehand serves to your forehand, aim down the line to their forehand; be ready to switch late to crosscourt backhand if they overcover forehand.
Re-evaluate default placements: avoid feeding a lefty’s forehand by habitually playing what you’d play to a righty’s backhand.
intermediaire: Use quick, aggressive backhands crosscourt into the lefty’s wide forehand to open the table.
Lock rallies to the lefty backhand with your forehand when that side is weaker or to reduce their forehand angles.
Exploit your own forehand pendulum serve that breaks into the lefty forehand to jam receive patterns.
avance: Develop instinctive mapping: catalogue the righty patterns that fail vs lefties and the normally unused patterns that succeed; execute without telegraphing.

erreurs_a_eviter: Waiting until the last second and lunging at a breaking serve so the racket drops and the return flies long
Mindlessly using righty-default placements that feed a lefty’s strengths

meta.article_title: July 11, 2011 - Where to Place Your Putaways

july_11_2011_where_to_place_your_putaway.probleme: Choosing putaway placement (smash or loop kill)
causes_communes: Always choosing the safest long diagonal so opponents anticipate and recover
Changing direction late without control leading to misses
Ignoring the opponent’s transition point (middle)

debutant: Use the safest spot (longest diagonal) for most putaways at lower levels where balls rarely return.
intermediaire: Aim for the long diagonal but switch last second down the line when the opponent shifts to cover it.
Target the opponent’s middle (elbow) to exploit decision delay between forehand and backhand.
avance: Place away from the opponent’s current position and momentum: if they step around to use forehand, attack down their forehand line; if they move wide forehand, go down backhand line to exploit reach.

erreurs_a_eviter: Telegraphing direction toward the longest diagonal
Forgetting that the middle is a moving target and requires precise reading of opponent position

july_4_2011_coaching_against_yourself.probleme: Unaddressed personal weaknesses in match play
july_4_2011_coaching_against_yourself.diagnostic: Player does not analyze own game as an opponent would.
causes_communes: Lack of self-analysis and tactical honesty

debutant: Imagine coaching an opponent to beat you; list the weaknesses and patterns you would target.
intermediaire: Turn that list into practice priorities and in-match adjustments to fix those weaknesses.
avance: Continuously update a self-scouting report and adapt training to remove the very patterns opponents exploit.

erreurs_a_eviter: Ignoring your own authoritative insights about your game

meta.article_title: March 7, 2011 - Do You Hit to the Three Spots?

march_7_2011_do_you_hit_to_the_three_spo.probleme: Random placement instead of strategic targeting
march_7_2011_do_you_hit_to_the_three_spo.diagnostic: Most attackers default to backhand where opponents are usually ready, especially early in rallies.
causes_communes: Failure to choose among wide forehand, wide backhand, and middle (elbow)
Telegraphing placement

debutant: Before contact, deliberately choose among wide forehand, wide backhand, or middle.
intermediaire: Avoid telegraphing; consider faking one way and going the other at the last second.
avance: Blend choice of spot with speed, spin, depth, and stroke selection to exploit uncovered zones.

erreurs_a_eviter: Mindlessly going to the backhand because it feels safe

meta.article_title: February 21, 2011 - Wait a split second longer when looping a push, then change directions

february_21_2011_wait_longer_then_change.probleme: Blockers anticipate standard loop timing and direction
february_21_2011_wait_longer_then_change.diagnostic: At the expected contact instant, blockers commit to forehand or backhand to cover likely crosscourt.
causes_communes: Predictable timing and crosscourt bias
Shorter down-the-line distance gives opponents more time to cover crosscourt than line if not used creatively

debutant: Set up as if looping crosscourt; at normal contact moment, delay a split second so the ball travels 6–12 inches, then go down the line.
intermediaire: From the wide forehand, use the delay-then-line change to exploit opponent movement toward crosscourt.
Recognize that faking line then going crosscourt is usually less effective since opponents default-cover crosscourt.
avance: Integrate micro-delays variably to disrupt blocker commitment without telegraphing the switch.

erreurs_a_eviter: Switching to crosscourt after faking line as a primary pattern
Failing to wait that split second required for the blocker to commit

meta.article_title: January 17, 2011 - Push with Purpose and Placement

january_17_2011_push_with_purpose_and_pl.probleme: Aimless pushing that feeds the opponent’s attack
january_17_2011_push_with_purpose_and_pl.diagnostic: Players push merely to keep the ball in play without spin/placement intent, often to easy loop zones.
causes_communes: Pushing six to twelve inches inside the backhand corner, inviting forehand step-around
Telegraphing direction early

debutant: Push with a clear purpose: very heavy backspin to force errors; or quick/fast pushes with late direction change to rush; or short pushes to deny looping.
Aim pushes over or even outside the backhand corner to reduce forehand step-around.
intermediaire: Use last-second change to quick-push wide forehand after aiming to backhand; then block to backhand to remove opponent forehand from rally (if forehand is stronger).
avance: Read rushed opponents for easier deception; counter with jab-blocks or counters once heavy step-around reveals direction early.

erreurs_a_eviter: Pushing to safe mid-backhand zones that are easy to loop
Telegraphing placement and pace on the push

meta.article_title: March 28, 2011 - Seven Placements and the Wide Angles

march_28_2011_seven_placements_and_the_w.probleme: Underusing extreme angles and proper directional targets
march_28_2011_seven_placements_and_the_w.diagnostic: Players hit into opponent’s middle forehand/backhand where reactions are easiest; avoid outside-corner angles due to perceived risk.
causes_communes: Defaulting to central lanes
Lack of sidespin control for outside-corner angles

debutant: Prefer wide corners and opponent’s elbow over middle forehand/backhand.
intermediaire: From a short middle ball, play either wide angle; from deep middle balls, employ topspin or sidespin loops to reach angles.
From your corners, use diagonal sidespin loops to land outside the opposite corner for maximal angle.
avance: Serve from a corner with breaking sidespin to create extreme wide-angle serves and expand the table you force the opponent to cover.

erreurs_a_eviter: Placing to middle forehand or middle backhand where opponent is set
Overhitting outside corners and missing off the side due to poor spin control

meta.article_title: May 16, 2011 - A Levels Approach to Tactics

may_16_2011_a_levels_approach_to_tactics.probleme: Selecting effective tactics for a given opponent
may_16_2011_a_levels_approach_to_tactics.diagnostic: Tactics can be mapped by combining your strengths/average/weaknesses vs opponent’s, yielding levels from +2 to -2.
causes_communes: Using negative or neutral combinations (e.g., weaknesses vs strengths) without awareness

debutant: Identify your strengths, average, and weaknesses; identify the opponent’s.
intermediaire: Aim for Level 2: your strengths vs opponent’s weaknesses; if unavailable, use Level 1 combinations.
Avoid Level -1 and -2 combinations that pit your weaknesses against the opponent’s stronger areas.
avance: During practice matches, analyze post-hoc which level each tactic belonged to; shift patterns toward positive levels.

erreurs_a_eviter: Falling into negative-level tactics without realizing it

june_13_2011_playing_the_fisher.probleme: Difficulty finishing points against a defensive topspin 'fisher'
june_13_2011_playing_the_fisher.diagnostic: Fisher returns deep, soft topspin with sidespin and length; bounce peak sits a half-step farther from table.
causes_communes: Over-attacking every ball and feeding the fisher’s rhythm
Attacking middle forehand/backhand where returns are easiest
Taking the ball too close to the table and getting jammed by longer arc

debutant: Adjust position: take a half step back to contact at top of bounce.
Prioritize placements to wide backhand and to the middle (slightly backhand side); avoid middle forehand/backhand.
intermediaire: Mix change-of-pace balls (softer loop, occasional block) to disrupt timing after several power attacks.
Favor backhand-side attacks where fisher has less range and spin; expect many returns back to your backhand.
avance: Blend loop and smash based on your strengths; use deception on smashes.
Apply sustained pressure until a short ball appears, then finish with a wide-angle or middle kill without telegraphing.

erreurs_a_eviter: Relentlessly smashing into the fisher’s groove without pace variation
Attacking to middle forehand/backhand where the fisher is most comfortable
Telegraphing the finishing direction on short balls

june_27_2011_complex_versus_simple_tacti.diagnostic: Too many variables to plan multi-shot sequences reliably; effective players find simple patterns.
causes_communes: Trying to script several shots ahead instead of selecting a few high-payoff patterns
Ignoring first-game information gathering

debutant: In game one, identify a few simple serve, receive, and rally tactics that set up your strengths or remove opponent strengths.
intermediaire: Serve to get the return you want (e.g., backspin for pushes if you loop backspin well; no-spin to avoid heavy pushes; topspin to enter topspin rallies).
Neutralize strengths (e.g., short to strong forehand then play out to backhand; return strong side-top serves deep; attack opponent’s middle).
avance: Standardize 2–3 serve tactics, 1–2 receive tactics, and 1–2 rally tactics that are ingrained and easily adapted per opponent.

erreurs_a_eviter: Chasing complex, pre-planned sequences instead of repeatable simple patterns

meta.article_title: May 30, 2011 - Play Into the Weird Stuff

may_30_2011_play_into_the_weird_stuff.probleme: Trouble vs unusual strokes or surfaces
may_30_2011_play_into_the_weird_stuff.diagnostic: Avoidance leaves you unprepared late in matches; short, angled returns cause most trouble.
causes_communes: Inside-out/sidespin loops or extra-flat backhands creating awkward angles
Weird surfaces that produce quick, short, angled replies

debutant: Proactively play into the problematic stroke/surface when you are ready to face it and build comfort.
intermediaire: Keep the ball deep to reduce opponent’s angles and buy reaction time.
avance: After comfort is built, selectively avoid the weakness while staying ready to handle it when forced into it.

erreurs_a_eviter: Avoiding the ‘weird’ pattern all match and arriving unprepared in key moments
Leaving balls short that come back quickly and at sharp angles
